6/ We lost the game, the crowd was going wild, and the first thing Steny thought about was making sure I was okay.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
5/ Hoyer was Majority Leader. A big deal. Had a large security detail. But within seconds of my error, he had forced his way out of the stands and into the locker room, to find me.

"You played a great game," he told me. "And you're a just a kid. You've got plenty of games left!"

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
4/ I walked straight into the locker room to sulk. Didn't even stop to collect my things in the dugout. I collapsed in despair.

And then, from down the hall, I hear a voice calling my name.

"Chris!"

"Chris!"

"Where are you? It's Steny!"

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
As leader, Nancy Pelosi wasn't afraid to take chances. In 2006, I was a long shot candidate - running against a 24-year incumbent Republican.

But in August, she came to Waterbury to campaign for (a much younger looking) me. A lot of people thought she was wasting her time. https://t.co/2DjAQYZlPn

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: RT @CitizenCohn: More to say about Pelosi soon, but this was just one of the moments from the ACA fight when she defied skeptics all over W‚Ä¶

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
7/ 2 months later, Congress passed the Affordable Care Act. And today, it's so popular the new Republican Congress won't dare touch it.

I had never seen any person do what Pelosi did that night. I've never seen it since. 

There hasn't been, and will not be, anyone like her.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
6/ She told us that it was time for us to stiffen our spines and march forward. She told us the country was counting on us. I watched her single handedly WILL the caucus to act. I watched her mettle change the entire mood of the room. 

When she was done, no one challenged her.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
5/ She told the room that there come times when leaders have a choice to make - stand up to the powerful status quo and change the world or give into to short term political expediency.

This was our moment, she told us, to save lives and lift millions out of health care poverty.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
4/ And then, when everyone had spoken, she picked up a handheld microphone. I expected her to give into the calls to give up.

But she didn't.

She did exactly the opposite.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 3/ I remember it like it was yesterday. Pelosi sat at the front of the room in the basement of the Capitol, and she listened politely to the calls for retreat. Even some of her most loyal progressive allies were begging her to ditch the ACA in the name of political expediency.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 2/ Many rank-and-file Democrats were in a panic, and they lined up at the microphone to tell Pelosi that it was time for us to give up on the Affordable Care Act. Or chop it up into little pieces - as some in the White House were suggesting.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
1/ There's one night I will remember most when thinking about Nancy Pelosi - the night I watched her single handedly save health care for 20 million Americans.

It was at the first Democratic caucus meeting after Scott Brown won the special Senate election in Massachusetts.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
Though I have this very Irish last name, I‚Äôm proud of my Polish heritage. I don‚Äôt speak the language, but I grew up surrounded by Polish culture. 

It makes me very proud to now be the Chairman of the U.S.-Poland Caucus in the Senate, and to be here in Warsaw.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
I never knew my great grandmother, but she was a huge influence on my mother, who spent every Sunday at her house in New Britain.

My grandfather, John, was also fascinated by politics. He would talk my ear off about his ideas, and later in life write me long letters on politics.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
Anna was a force to be reckoned with. A strong, domineering personality, she paid close attention to politics and was a fierce advocate for women‚Äôs rights. 

She and Alexander had four children, including my grandfather, John (furthest to the left). https://t.co/hCVX1XJy8U

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
Shortly thereafter, she met another Polish immigrant, Alexander Lewczyk, at a party in the city. 

He lived in a thriving Polish neighborhood in a small city in central Connecticut - New Britain. 

They fell in love, married, and settled in New Britain. https://t.co/ytsHjny6Za

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
At 16, her father put her in his horse drawn cart and sent her away to catch a boat, by herself, to America, where her older sister lived.

She arrived at Ellis Island around the turn of the century and got a job as a maid in New York City.

Here she is with her sister. https://t.co/OgHGRX7vWK

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
So every Polish-American has a story. As I visit Warsaw this week, I want to tell you a part of mine. 

My great grandmother, Anna Penk, had a rough life in rural Poland. Her mother died in childbirth and her father‚Äôs second wife was disinterested in raising her. https://t.co/RuVft0bjpH

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
10/ This is a dystopia, but a true possibility. Trump and the new right are more aligned than ever today.

So it's time we call out the new right for its radical belief structure, before it's too late.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 9/ If the new right wins power through its alignment with Trump, what is likely to occur is no shift in economic power; just a replacement of participatory democracy with some version of a Christian theocracy that rolls back individual and civil rights.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
8/ Similarly, the new rights talks a lot about destroying the "regime" of economic/media/academic power, but it's all bluster. They provide almost no ideas of how to do this.

In the end, the new right feels like a creative populist front for conservative finance and tech elites.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
7/ Tellingly, the new right talks a lot about social but not economic restraints.

"I no longer believe democracy and freedom are compatible", says the new right's patron, Peter Thiel.

But what he wants is less consumer regulation and more freedom for monopoly power.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
6/ Democracy is also dangerous to the new right bc it allows progressives to win power. And the new right views the left as an existential threat to America. "The true enemy", said Arizona's Blake Masters.

Any means necessary to destroy the left is justified by the new right.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
5/ Further, the new right believes democracy has outlived its usefulness. Democracy is too inefficient, and voters are too dumb.

Curtis Yarvin, the intellectual muse of the new right, supports a monarchy, writing: "Democracy...is just impossible. With today‚Äôs voters, at least".

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 4/ Essentially, the new right wants to roll back American social progress 100 years. Women should know their place (behind men), and "multiculturalism" is corrosive. America needs a dominant culture, says the new right, and it should be white and patriarchal.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
3/ The new right believes that humans require strict behavior constraints, and that government should be organized to impose these constraints through a type of Christian neo-theocracy.

That's why the new right supports bans on abortion and homosexuality.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
2/ At its heart, the new right represents a rejection of classic liberalism - the idea that individual rights, free but fair markets, and democracy best secure happiness.

"A free life is hell on earth", one of their thought leaders wrote this weekend.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
The new right is the growing intellectual backbone of the Trump movement. After reading this article over the summer, I went on a deep dive to learn it.

You need to know it too. It's not fringe. It's real and it's dangerous.

1/ Here's a quick primer. 
https://t.co/yqd0jY9NA4

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
7/ Everyone I met was sincere and I do think there is a genuine desire of many of these innovators to do good.

But today, it feels like we work for technology, instead of technology working for us. This needs to change. Fast.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 6/ Finally, it's clear that there is still no way for the social media companies to police themselves into responsible behavior. The algorithms are too opaque, the platforms are too intentionally addictive, the protections for kids are too weak.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 5/ Also a lack of acknowledgement here that the last 25 years of technological change has been uniquely dislocating. For instance, EVERY SINGLE leader I met w compared social media to the printing press, arguing that every big new technology is met with early na√Øve skepticism.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 4/ What I found in my meetings is a view of innovation and increased connectivity as a near universal net good. Feels like a bit of a innovation hamster wheel. Not enough leaders seriously asking - does the innovation actually increase citizens' happiness?

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 3/ But for many, tech now overwhelms and vexes us, addicting our children to screens, funneling users into information silos, elevating the most extreme voices, and consolidating power and wealth into the select expert elites who know how manipulate the technology.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 2/ I feel from my constituents an increasingly distrust of and exhaustion with technology. Technology promised to make our lives easier, help us build more fulfilling personal connections, and give us access to new economic opportunities.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
Finishing a trip to San Fran/Silicon Valley. Met with many smart and thoughtful tech leaders.

But there's still a big disconnect between how average Americans think about technology vs. how the industry views tech. It's a dangerous divide.

1/ A few thoughts from the trip.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
Good morning. 

If Republicans win this fall they are going to pass a national abortion ban, eliminate the $2,000 Medicare cap on drug prices, and put a sunset on Social Security. 

You know why I know this? Because they keep telling us.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
9/ Bowling balls are hard to stop. We've seen it over and over - Vietnam, Iraq, Syria etc. Leaders often don't want to look "weak" by questioning paths to conflict. 

But here, we can step up efforts to protect Taiwan, without totally throwing out decades of successful policy.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 8/ It's fair to counter that we shouldn't make policy based on China's irrational hurt feelings. Okay, but our China portfolio isn't just Taiwan. It's trade, human rights, NKorea, climate, fentanyl, etc. Shouldn't we consider how Taiwan policy changes affect the whole portfolio?

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 7/ Further, there's no need for an explicit defense guarantee. China has already priced in a full U.S. defense if they invade, so what do we get by making Taiwan's defense our explicit policy? Again, it's tough talk without enough upside to counter the provocatory downside.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 6/ It's a policy that looks strong and tough on China, but does it actually protect our interests? The answer is no. Recognizing Taiwan doesn't actually protect Taiwan; it will just enrage our allies and possibly provoke China into retaliation and a quicker invasion.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 5/ But many in Congress and the think tank ecosystem argue that the U.S. must go much further - by ending "strategic ambiguity", recognizing Taiwan, and promising to fully defend Taiwan if China invades. A full reversal of decades of bipartisan consensus on Taiwan policy.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 4/ In this context, our Taiwan policy MUST change. We need to expedite and increase arms sales. We should help Taiwan join international bodies. We should sanction Chinese officials who undermine Taiwan. We should fight Chinese anti-Taiwan propaganda.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
3/ Our policy is purposely fuzzy. And it has worked.

But now, things are changing. China is getting more aggressive. Undermining and isolating Taiwan. Building up its military. Flexing left and right. Hinting at an invasion in the near future.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 2/ For decades, the U.S. has helped secure peace on the island of Taiwan, largely bc of a policy through which we a) neither recognize Taiwan's independence nor recognize China's claim to Taiwan; and b) help Taiwan defend itself without explicitly guaranteeing their security.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
U.S. foreign policy often builds like a runaway bowling ball. An idea gets rolling, develops uncontrollable momentum, and then, before anyone has really evaluated the idea's merit, it's knocking over everything.

1/ This could be happening today on Taiwan policy. Let me explain:

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
10/ The invasion of Afghanistan was just. But the right path would have been a quicker exit rather than a 20 year occupation. 

The continued magical thinking that we could have won Afghanistan if we stayed longer is bound to get us into trouble later. 

Hubris breeds hubris.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
9/ Finally, there was no world in which Biden could have just "stuck it out". That would have required tens of thousands more troops and a resumption of deadly fighting with the Taliban.

And the design flaws of the first 20 years wouldn't have vanished if we stayed longer.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
8/ For centuries, the Afghans have resisted conquest and control. The power and strength of the instinct to fight America and the West was always going to be stronger than the willingness to work with us.

Resistance is in the soul of Afghanistan.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 7/ More importantly, there was likely NEVER going to be a plan - even if it was informed by a better cultural understanding - that could impose a foreign power's will on Afghanistan. Sometimes, there is no American plan that will work.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 6/ But if you don't know how to properly spend money, who to partner with, how to build sustainable governments, etc, than there's no amount of money that will fix a fundamentally flawed strategy.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 5/ The "can do" spirit of our military is its greatest strength and liability. In Afghanistan, the military's failed to understand that a paper thin understanding of Afghan culture and society was destined to lead to planning failure. But, admirably, they couldn't accept failure.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 4/ Every time I visited Afghanistan, a new smart general would explain to me why the previous general screwed up and how his new plan (derived from maybe 30 days of on-the-ground learning) would get things on the right track.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
3/ From the start, we didn't understand Afghanistan, a country wildly different from and more complicated than Iraq.

And our structure of rotating generals and soldiers in and out 12 months at a time meant that we were destined to never learn Afghanistan.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
2/ Patraeus says the problem was a) we refused to stay longer; b) we spent too little $ and on the wrong stuff; and c) we didn't understand Afghanistan.

What he fails to realize is that (a) and (b) don't matter if (c) is true.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
I greatly respect General Patraeus, but there is real danger is allowing the magical thinking of "if we had spent more money or stayed longer everything would have been fine" to persist.

1/ A few thoughts on why "more" wouldn't have fixed Afghanistan.
https://t.co/oEipKiAn71

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
I had clear bottom lines on what had to be part of the Electoral Count Reform Act in order for me to put my name on the bill.

It had to meaningfully constrain bad actors at BOTH the federal and state level who are trying to steal elections.

The bill we introduced does that.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
RT @moneillsf: Getting ready to go live from Washington on @CNN with @amanpour.

You can tune in live on CNN at 6.40pm back home, 1.40pm ET‚Ä¶

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
6/ This bill isn't a comprehensive attempt to reform our elections. This bill just aims to make sure that presidential elections can't be stolen through a manipulation of the electoral college process.

We have much more to do to secure elections and make sure everyone can vote.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 5/ Finally, this bill makes clear the Vice President's role is just ceremonial. Trump's hail mary play - the VP blocking certification - is no longer even a remote possibility.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 4/ The bill also removes an ambiguous provision in the 1887 law that Trump argued allows state legislatures to appoint their own electors if they judged there to be fraud in the election. Now, states won't be able to change the rules of how electors are chosen after the election.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 3/ Next, this bill makes it harder for members of Congress to object to the certified results submitted by a state. Right now, it only takes one Senator or one House member with a conspiracy theory to force a vote. The new threshold is 20% of House/Senate members.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 2/ First, this bill would make sure that every state correctly certifies election results. How? By creating an expedited new court process to stop fraud if a state government attempts to ignore the will of the voters by sending more than one set of results, or none at all.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
üö® NEWS: I'm proud to be part of bipartisan group of 16 Senators that just introduced a bill to rewrite the 1887 Electoral Count Act to prevent attempts to steal the presidency with fraudulent elector slates. 

1/ This is important. Here's what the bill does:

tweet_text: 5/ The Illinois red flag law allows police to obtain an order (even without the consent of the parents), and with additional funding (also part of the new gun law), it's likely the Highland Park Police would have known that this was a text book case for a red flag order.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
4/ But under the new law, each time Crimo bought a gun in 2020, the FBI would have been required to call the Highland Park Police to notify them.

This would have been key information, bc now the Highland Park Police would know that this dangerous kid was stockpiling weapons.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 3/ In 2020, Crimo began to buy military style guns. Under current law, the FBI simply checks criminal databases and if there is no arrest (which there wasn't for Crimo), the sale goes through. So the Highland Park police likely didn't know this dangerous kid was buying guns.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
2/ The Highland Park killer was known to police. In 2019 police interceded when Crimo tried to kill himself with a machete and again when he threatened to kill family members.

At the time, Crimo didn't own a gun, so a red flag law process wasn't relevant.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
The new gun bill requires that local police be notified anytime a 18-20 yr old buys a gun. It also provides funding to help police better administer red flag laws.

These two provisions could have prevented the Highland Park shooting.

And that mandated call to local police could have set that process in motion.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 5/ Or maybe the wait would have allowed his moment of crisis to pass. Or maybe if the gun store had told Ramos that as a condition of buying these guns, a call was going to be made to the local police department, it might have scared him straight.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
4/ They would have had time to intervene bc the new law creates a de facto waiting period, of anywhere from 3-10 days, before an 18-20 yr old can buy a gun. 

Also, the waiting period could have prevented Ramos from getting the guns at all before the last day of school.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 3/ The police likely knew Ramos was dangerous. That call would have given them key information that a kid in crisis was rushing out to buy guns the minute he turned 18. The police could have taken steps to intervene.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
2/ Most importantly, the bill requires that no gun can be sold to an 18 year old without a call being placed by the FBI to the local police to check on the status of the buyer.

Reporting suggests Ramos was known to the local police - they had been to his house multiple times.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 9/ Finally, our bill invests over $2 billion in community safety by funding community anti-violence programs in our cities, and school safety initiatives, by increasing funds for the existing bipartisan STOP School Violence program.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 8/ Other mental health investments include help for pediatricians to do telehealth consults with mental health professionals, money for more school based mental health centers, support for suicide hotlines, and mental health first aid programs.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 7/ Our bill makes a historic $11 billion investment in our nation's broken mental health system. The most important thing we do it build out a new, nationwide system of mental health clinics, targeting the most underserved areas of the nation. This is a huge deal.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 6/ The bill clarifies who needs to register as a federal firearms dealer, to make sure that every true commercial gun seller is conducting background checks. This provision could get thousands of additional guns sales into the background check system.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 5/ The bill includes the first every comprehensive federal criminal statute banning gun trafficking and straw purchasing. This allows law enforcement to put a stop to the flow of illegal guns into our cities.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 4/ For under 21 year old buyers, we build an enhanced, longer background check, including a call to the local police department to see if the kid is in crisis. This enhanced check can take from 3-10 days, providing for a critical "cooling off" period for young people in crisis.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 3/ After decades of trying, we're finally closing the boyfriend loophole. That means that if you assault your girlfriend or your ex-girlfriend, you lose your ability to buy or own a gun. You can get your rights back, but years later, only for one time, non-repeat offenders.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 2/ The bill funds the implementation of crisis intervention orders in every state, including so called "red flag" laws. These laws allow courts to temporarily take guns away from people who are threatening to kill themselves or others.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
Here it is, folks - the Bipartisan Safer Communities Act, the most significant piece of anti-gun violence legislation in nearly 30 years.

This bill is going to save thousands of lives.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: The plan is to work hard at a compromise for the next 10 days. Hopefully we succeed and the Senate can vote on a bipartisan bill that saves lives. name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
Imagine being 9 years old, and watching your friend get shot through the nose and collapse dead in front of you.

The headline, for good reason, is the number of kids dead. But a huge part of the story, in shooting after shooting, is the lifetime of trauma for the survivors. https://t.co/4C4pVdX37E

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: I'm sorry to keep passing news like this along, but having been present for one of these nights, I just want you all to understand what is happening right now, as the bodies are being identified. It's f-ing awful, and it's just our choice whether we want this to continue. https://t.co/nPrxA7uPLE

name: Chris Murphy

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
The part you often don't see - the grisly process of identifying the bodies in a mass shooting - is as horrific as it sounds. And the horror is x100 when those bodies are 2nd and 3rd and 4th graders.

This is our choice - to keep forcing parents to go through this. https://t.co/8egQR5hHTr

name: Chris Murphy

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:

tweet_text:

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 7/ Now, Putin has two ways out. Back down, or proceed with a plan he never really wanted - an expensive, costly, and potentially disastrous invasion of the largest country in Europe.

7/ Then he hung up. 

He spent the rest of day relentlessly pressuring McConnell agree to my demands for votes on background checks bills. 

By midnight, Reid had succeeded. He got the votes.

The lesson I learned - there's nothing like having Harry Reid in your corner.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
6/ "Chris," he said, "A lot of people TALK about filibustering. A lot of people CALL ME about filibustering. But nobody actually DOES IT."

"I can't tell you what to do. But what I can tell you is this - if you're going to do this, then stop calling people, and go DO IT."

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
5/ Harry didn't like grandstanding, and a filibuster is the ultimate "look at me" move. Harry preferred exercising power quietly. Forcefully but quietly. 

But I had no other options, so right before I went to the floor, I called Harry.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
4/ And for the next four years, he worked with me to try to advance the cause of anti-gun violence. 

But when I decided to launch a filibuster after the Orlando shooting, I was nervous, because I was going to grind the Senate to a halt. And I hadn't told Harry - my leader.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
3/ Harry was old school. His convictions mattered more than his politics. If something was right, he was ready to risk everything.

So after Sandy Hook - he took a big risk. He broke w the NRA and backed a background checks bill the NRA hated. He put it on the floor for a vote.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
2/ First, you've got to understand that Harry and the NRA started out as allies. His NRA endorsement was an important calling card for him for a long time.

But as the NRA got more extreme, Harry simply couldn't stomach it. He couldn't stay silent.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
I feel so lucky to have served under Harry Reid, and so sad he's gone.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 9/ I‚Äôm so proud of my Pop. He was a strong, quiet type. And I wish I had tried harder to pierce his veil and learn more about his life. But he led by example. Just like so many great Americans we celebrate today -  Veterans Day 2021. https://t.co/HoHMBeUACM

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
8/ Like most veterans, Pop‚Äôs commitment to service didn‚Äôt end once he came home.

He built an engineering business in Connecticut, was an active member of his church, helped lead efforts to build affordable senior housing in Wethersfield. And that‚Äôs just the tip of the iceberg. https://t.co/6s28qEqzLX

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
7/ He got back to Connecticut in a snow storm, Christmas 1945. The cabbie who picked him up at Union Station in Hartford, and drove to Wethersfield through the storm, wouldn‚Äôt accept payment from a returning young vet.

16 months later, his first child, my father, was born. https://t.co/qy7Izc8dSS

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
6/ After Berlin fell, Pop couldn‚Äôt come home. There were bridges to be built in the Pacific. In August 1945 he was on a ship bound for the Pacific theater when the bombs were dropped on Japan. 

He was diverted to the Philippines and built bridges there for a few months. https://t.co/xyMY0gNfNv

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
5/ Pop wasn‚Äôt infantry, but he was always in harm‚Äôs way. His job required him to be constantly on the front lines (since bridges came before the troop advances).

And the speed of construction meant safety wasn‚Äôt always first. Here he is after being hit in the head by a crane. https://t.co/NGLNvzpFZq

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
4/ These are photos of the bridges he helped build across Belgium, France, and Germany.

One story Pop told was of the time Patton pulled up to a bridge that wasn‚Äôt 100% finished and Pop had to nervously explain to the famously impatient general that it wasn‚Äôt safe to cross yet. https://t.co/O7N4qEfXVa

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
3/ After D-Day, one of the primary obstacles confronting the Allies were all the bridges that had been destroyed or damaged by Hitler in an effort to frustrate the Allies‚Äô advance. 

Pop was assigned to Patton‚Äôs Third Army to build and repair bridges, and to do it FAST. https://t.co/HkdE6QrGS5

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
2/ Pop had just received his engineering degree from Duke, so he was recruited to join the Army Corp of Engineers.

During a one week leave in December 1943 he married my grandmother. Days later, he was shipped off to Europe. They wouldn‚Äôt see each other again for two years. https://t.co/wOFrGxv4Qc

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
1/ As we celebrate Veterans Day, I want to lift up the story of my late grandfather, Val Murphy (his grandkids called him ‚ÄúPop‚Äù), and the unique role he played in World War Two.

Here he is -  a new recruit - in 1943, with my great Uncle Fred. Pop is on the left. https://t.co/1Fra39jkEv

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
FYI here's the article with a great narrative on gun laws in early America:

https://t.co/6yjqCDpczh

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
5/ So this idea that the 2nd Amendment prohibits these laws is a completely modern fabrication. 

The people who wrote and approved the Bill of Rights were often the same who supported laws controlling the public carrying of weapons. That's the truth.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
4/ As an example, Alabama's 1837 law was entitled "An act to suppress the evil practice of carrying weapons secretly.‚Äù

Early America was full of laws allowing government to regulate guns in public. It was viewed as a perfectly constitutional exercise of government authority.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 3/ And it's not like independence from Britain - or the adoption of the 2nd Amendment - changed anything. In the late 1700s, North Carolina and Virginia passed laws restricting carrying guns in public. In the 1800s, 38 more states joined the list.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
2/ Colonial America was full of laws regulating who could carry guns in America. 

As early as 1686, New Jersey enacted a law against wearing weapons because they induced ‚Äúgreat Fear and Quarrels.‚Äù Massachusetts followed in 1750.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
1/ The idea that the Constitution doesn't allow government to control the carrying of guns in public would have been MYSTIFYING to our founding fathers.

Why? Because our founders passed tons of laws regulating the carrying of guns. Here's the quick story.
https://t.co/JOeuIdUiuO

5/ Mike is going to stick w Biden. But he still struggles w where to get the truth about what‚Äôs going on.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
5/ So Aretha is still out of work. She applies for jobs every day but she needs a job that pays a living wage, not a job that keeps her in poverty while making her ineligible for UI or SNAP. 

In short, she needs work to pay. And right now, it doesn‚Äôt.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
4/ But she found that when she got offered jobs, it was for far less than she made at DMV and mostly it was for less than 40 hours a week. 

‚ÄúI need 5 days a week to pay my bills,‚Äù she told me.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
3/ Aretha liked that job, so she stayed on unemployment hoping she would be rehired. But when that didn‚Äôt happen, she started furiously looking for work. 

Sure, she still had unemployment, but she WANTED to work. Especially since she knew UI wasn‚Äôt forever.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
2/ For years, she was employed as a food service worker at the Department of Motor Vehicles in Wethersfield. It was a good paying, full time job, just a bus ride from her home. 

Last year, when DMV employees began working from home, she got laid off.

name: Chris Murphy

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 10/ Today I‚Äôm grieving for all the families who lost loved ones twenty years ago today. And I‚Äôm also remembering the day that set in motion the work of millions of Americans chose, in the wake of that terrible day, to try to make their country better and safer.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 9/ I was deeply uncomfortable about the way in which America over militarized our response to 9/11. But I didn‚Äôt want America to withdraw from the world. So I set about the work of properly learning the lessons of Iraq and Afghanistan, and course correcting U.S. foreign policy.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
8/ People always ask me why I spend so much time working on foreign policy and national security issues. 

It all comes back to 9/11. My generation was formed by it. We are defined by it. The choices we have made since then are derivative of it.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
7/ But I was a state legislator with no role to play in the biggest issue that affected my generation. I grew frustrated. 

So in early 2005, just over 3 years after 9/11, I decided to make a long shot race for Congress. There I could make a difference I thought.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
6/ Within two years America was at war in two far off nations.

I knew Afghanistan was the right war, but as my friends were being sent to fight a war of choice in Iraq, I became more and more worried we had made a costly error as a nation.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
5/ The national conversation naturally launched into talk of retribution. 

That night I watched with my parents as Bush declared ‚ÄúWe will make no distinction between the terrorists who committed these acts and those that harbored them.‚Äù

This made perfect sense to me.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
4/ I was glued to the TV the rest of the morning, making occasional calls to see if I could connect with friends in the city. 

Eventually I headed to my parents house in Wethersfield where my parents had cable. We would learn that we lost 3 family friends who were in the towers.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 3/ As a poor state legislator who spent my entire salary on law school tuition, I didn‚Äôt own a proper television or have cable back then. So I pulled out a tiny black and white set and found the antenna only picked up one channel - WTNH.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 2/ I was at a meeting at Southington High School, just around the corner from my one bedroom apartment. I watched the initial reports of a plane crash on the small televisions in the school‚Äôs library. It looked like an accident at first, and I headed back home.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text: 1/ I was 27 on September 11, 2001. A second term state legislator. For people like me, in their formative stage of public service in 2001, 9/11 was definitional. It charted our course.

name: Chris Murphy
tweet_text:
I grew up with all three. 

Jeff and his sister Pam were childhood friends. I looked up to Dave, one the ‚Äúcool older kids‚Äù. And everybody knew the Keane kids and their father, the ever present sports dad. 

Little Wethersfield lost a lot that day.  https://t.co/vQZE94kVjz
